meanings.definition: The measure of a material's ability to resist the flow of electric current.
meanings.sent1: The resistivity of the wire determines how easily electricity can pass through it.
meanings.sent2: Copper has low resistivity, allowing electricity to flow efficiently.
meanings.sent3: The resistivity of the rubber band made it a poor choice for conducting electricity in the science experiment.
meanings.sent4: Her determination to finish the project was like the resistivity of a strong metal against electricity.
meanings.sent5: The resistivity of the material was so high that even a lightning bolt couldn't pass through.

meanings.definition: The property of a substance that hinders the flow of heat through it.
meanings.sent1: Insulation works by increasing the resistivity of the walls, keeping the heat inside.
meanings.sent2: The resistivity of the ceramic material made it ideal for keeping the coffee warm.
meanings.sent3: The resistivity of the ice cube was so high that it refused to melt even in the sun.
meanings.sent4: The resistivity of the blanket was like a shield against the cold winter air.
meanings.sent5: The resistivity of the fabric was so effective that it blocked out all the heat from the sun.

meanings.definition: The degree to which a material opposes the passage of magnetic flux.
meanings.sent1: The resistivity of the metal affected how easily the magnetic field could pass through it.
meanings.sent2: The resistivity of the iron core altered the strength of the electromagnet.
meanings.sent3: The resistivity of the paperclip made it challenging for the magnet to pick it up.
meanings.sent4: The resistivity of the material created a magnetic barrier that repelled the magnets.
meanings.sent5: The resistivity of the substance was so strong that it created a magnetic force field around it.
